candidates.title: Are These Towering Snow Walls in Massachusetts?
candidates.content:
Claim:
A photograph shows snow walls lining a highway in Massachusetts.
Rating:
Miscaptioned
About this rating
A photograph showing high walls of snow lining the edges of a highway has been circulating on the Internet since at least 2007. Popular memes have claimed (for humorous effect) that the picture was taken in Massachusetts, or (less homorously) in Canada:
The image actually captures a stretch of road near the Japanese city of Towada in Aomori prefecture.
The photograph was taken by Mihai Apostu and posted to his blog, "A Romanian in Japan," in April 2007:
Before heading down town we decided to take a walk up to Towada. On the way to Towada starting from April thh Gold Line Route is opened. This year's amount of snow was smaller than last year but the Hakkoda Walls are still big. Last year the walls of snow on both sides of the road were 9( nine) metres tall. This year there were only 6 metres of snow that guided us to Tsuta Onsen.
According to a sightseeing guide for the Aomori region of Japan, the Hakkoda Walls are quite a tourist attraction. Heavy snowfalls frequently close the corridor during the winter, but when the spring season approaches the Hakkoda Snowplow Squad gets to work and clears the road:
National Highway 103, commonly known as the Hakkoda-Towada Gold Line, is a popular sightseeing route in Aomori.8 km of this Hakkoda-Towada Gold Line stretching from Sukayu to Yachi Hot Springs is closed off in winter, but thanks to the efforts of the Hakkoda Snowplow Squad, they plow through the snow from both ends to meet at Kasamatsu Pass in late March, creating a stunning snow corridor.
In some places the walls of snow reach a height of 9 m, allowing visitors to enjoy magnificent views of the vivid blue of the sky contrasted against the white of the snow in perfect harmony.
The road opens to general traffic on April 1, but before this, a Hakkoda walk is held every year to walk through this snow corridor, and many people take part in the event.
candidates.description: The walls are formed with specially-designed snow plows.

result.explanation: The news caption claims a photograph shows high snow walls lining a highway in Massachusetts. Source 1 explicitly states that a photograph showing high snow walls lining a highway has circulated online, with claims it was taken in Massachusetts. However, the source also debunks this claim, revealing the photo was actually taken in Japan, near the city of Towada.  Therefore, while the caption accurately describes the content of the image, the location specified is incorrect.
result.supporting_points: Source 1: A photograph showing high walls of snow lining the edges of a highway has been circulating on the Internet since at least 2007. Popular memes have claimed (for humorous effect) that the picture was taken in Massachusetts...

final_result.explanation: The original news caption states that the image depicts high walls of snow lining the edges of a highway in Massachusetts. Internal validation reveals a confidence score of 0, indicating that the image shows snow walls along a highway but doesn't provide any information to confirm the location is Massachusetts.  The internal check correctly identifies a lack of evidence to support the claim that the photo was taken in Massachusetts.  External validation provides a confidence score of 8.  It confirms the image shows high snow walls on a highway, but it also decisively refutes the claim that the photo was taken in Massachusetts.  Multiple sources confirm the image originates from Japan, near Towada city.  The external validation process effectively identifies and corrects the inaccurate location information in the original caption, leveraging reliable external sources to support its findings. The disagreement between the internal check (lack of location evidence) and external check (incorrect location claim) is resolved by the external check's stronger confidence score and factual evidence from other sources.  The external check's higher score is due to the availability of verifiable information from reliable sources which are publicly available, corroborating that the location claim was incorrect.  Given that external sources identify the true location as Japan, and that the location specified in the original caption is demonstrably wrong, the caption is considered to be out-of-context.
final_result.validation_summary: Internal validation identified the lack of location evidence within the image itself, leading to a low confidence score. External validation confirmed the image's visual description (snow walls on a highway) but corrected the erroneous location claim (Massachusetts), supporting the conclusion that the caption is out-of-context.
